Rhoda is a 26-year-old lady who is married and blessed with four children. Her husband is employed and supports her in bringing in more income for the family. She has been running a retail shop business for five years now and is happy to make a profit of about 40,000 Kenya shillings every month.

This will be her first loan with VisionFund Kenya after she was introduced by her group members, and she plans to use it to add more stock of retail goods in her shop including sugar, flour, rice, margarine, cooking oils, etc. She plans to use the anticipated profits to take care of her family and also save some to help with the education of her children.

In future she plans to expand her business and see her children educated further.

loans.use: to add more stock of retail goods in her shop

loans.name: Sonishka

texts.en:
Sonishka is one of those hundreds of people who had a deal with Kiva and now she hurries to have one more profitable partnership. She lives with her husband in Kadjaran city in the Syunik region. Sonishka works as a trader and her business is the only source of her family income. She rents a stall where she sells vegetables, fruits, berries, dairy-products and also some seedlings for farmers for their seasonal cultivation activities. Sonishka’s stall is very popular in her city, since her prices are cheap and she has a great assortment of products that she refreshes once every two days. Since receiving her first Kiva loan, the number of customers and her sales of products have greatly increased. 

Sonishka is requesting a loan to buy a lot of vegetables and fruits from local farmers to resell. She hopes to have success in her business.

loans.use: to buy a lot of vegetables and fruits from local farmers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase construction materials such as cement and bricks in order to renovate and repair the family home

loans.name: Nyamvula

texts.en:
Nyamvula is a hardworking business woman who lives in her own house that does not have electricity nor piped water.  She is married with six school going children.

Nyamvula has operated a charcoal selling business for the past six years. Her potential clients are neighbors and passersby. 

With the loan, Nyamvula wants to purchase sacks of charcoal to resell.  She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal to resell.

loans.name: Eman

texts.en:
(Because Eman is a conservative woman, she asked her husband to take her place in the picture.)

Eman is 25 years old married woman.  Her husband is a soldier. 

Because of her sense of responsibility, Eman supports her family buy working.  She has sold food products in her house to neighbors and friends, for the past two years. 

Now Eman is seeking a youth loan to buy more food products for her business as she is receiving more requests from her customers.

loans.use: To buy more food products for her business.

loans.name: Tishitoo Group

texts.en:
The three ladies in the photograph are part of the group called Tsuishitoo who live in the Teshie neighborhood.

They sell wine glasses, cutlery sets, cooked rice with corn beef, sardines, eggs, ceramic and plastic products.  The group representative is Kai, a 45 year old married woman with two dependable children.  Kai and her husband live together with their children and jointly ensure that family expenses are covered. 

Kai did not attend school. For nearly 17 years, she has sold ceramics, cutlery sets and plastic products.  She operates her business with passion enabling her to meet her needs and those of her children.  She gets her supplies from a market in Accra. 

Seeking to satisfy her customers, Kai is requesting a loan with the other group's members.  This loan will enable each member to meet the demands from customers and to make more profit.

loans.use: to buy and sell ceramics, cutlery sets and plastic products to customers.

loans.name: Ruqaya

texts.en:
Ruqaya is 38 years old married lady who has run a small general store in her community for many years.  

She offers a variety of grocery items at reasonable prices and has retained many customers who regularly shop at her store. 

She makes enough money to provide for her family.  To fully stocked her store Ruqaya requested a loan of 50,000 to buy rice, sugar and flour from the market at lower rates. 

In this way Ruqaya will be able to meet the increasing demand from customers consistently.  Ruqaya also wishes to utilize part of her revenues to increase her business capital.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar and flour .

loans.name: Lillian

texts.en:
Hello world! Meet Lillian, a mother of three. She is a mixed famer in the Kisii area of Kenya who raises cows and poultry to produce milk and eggs to sell. Lillian also grows tea and vegetables on her farm. She has been a famer for at least 10 years! Lillian has no plans to quit in future as she finds farming to be not only fulfilling but also lucrative. However, her biggest business challenges are the poor road network and the lack of market.  

Lillian is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Juhudi Kilimo to construct a cow shed.  Her loan will help her to significantly improve the health and hygiene or her animals. Constructing a cow shed will also come in handy when she scales up and introduces zero-grazing. The long-term impact of her loan will be an increase in productivity and improved animal health. Lillian will use the income from her loan to provide for her children’s education. She is striving to improve her family’s quality of life by constantly increasing her income.

loans.use: to construct a cow shed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for renovations to expand her salon and purchase treatment machines, materials, and cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to such items as toothpaste, oil, and soap to offer for sale

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en:
Doreen is a 32-year-old married lady.  Her spouse Collins adds an additional income to facilitate and meet their family's needs as they are trusting God to bless them with children.  Doreen has been operating a chemist (pharmacy) for a period of three years, earning an income of KES 10,000.

Doreen is now requesting her third loan of KES 54,000 with VisionFund Kenya and intends to use this amount to expand her chemist by adding more bulk stock to meet her clients' expectations. She plans to use the anticipated income to buy medicine in bulk and hopes to become both a retailer and a wholesaler vendor to her clients in the near future.

loans.use: To buy bulk drugs to add to the pharmacy and meet her customers' expectations

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes and accessories for her business

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira suffered from breast cancer, and about three years ago she had surgery where one of her breasts was removed. Ever since, she’s been on therapy and is desperately now seeking your financial help to finish off her therapy and buy medication as well.  

Elvira is a 50-year-old woman of Egyptian ethnicity in Albania; she lives in the city of Korca, in the southeastern part of the country.  She’s got two children, who are fifteen and eighteen; one of them, her daughter, was born with a disability: her arms are very short and she has difficulty doing things on her own most of the time. 

Elvira’s husband does a labour job at a tobacco factory in the city, while Elvira and her daughter are receiving disability income; thus, she can’t afford to complete her therapy. She is thanking you in advance for your compassion.

loans.use: to complete the therapy and buy medications for her illness

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans is 42 years old and is married with two dependent children. He rents an apartment in the community of Teshie, in Ghana-Accra. For several years, Evans has been sewing men’s shirt and trousers to sell to customers. Evans pays rapt attention to his business and is an entrepreneurial man with a desire to get ahead. 

Evans is requesting a 1,100 GHS loan to buy wholesale material and other accessories to use to sew clothing to sell to customers. He has had several previous loans and is very happy to continue working with ID-Ghana and Kiva. His dream is to further improve his house.

loans.use: to buy wholesale material and other accessories to sew clothing to sell to customers

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza is 40 years old married woman who has four children.  Her husband is a laborer. 

It was very tough for Aziza to manage her household needs with the small income of her husband.  Therefore she decided to earn money. 

For this purpose Aziza started selling cloth.  She buys a variety of cloth on the wholesale market and sells in her area.  Now she is playing a very important role for her family. 

Aziza applied for a loan of 45000 from PKR to purchase a variety of cloth in different colors after taking in account the taste and choices of her customers. 

She is in her sixth loan cycle with good credit history.

loans.use: to purchase a of cloth in different colors.

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin is a 36-year-old man who is married and blessed with three children aged 12, 8 and 9 months respectively. He has been selling ripe bananas for a period of seven years and getting a monthly profit of 42,000 Kenyan shillings per month. 

This is his forth loan cycle from VisionFund Kenya and he plans to use it to add more stock of bananas for resale to his clients. He anticipates to use the income generated to expand the business more.

He in future hopes to be successful in business.

loans.use: to add stock of ripe bananas for resale.

loans.name: Nongowa Tra Cen Ii Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) is very pleased to present to you this team of hardworking and dedicated teachers from the Eastern city of Kenema, Sierra Leone. Martin is the chosen leader of the team of teachers. He is 37 years old and is married to a trader. The couple has three children. Martin has been a teacher for 15 years.

The Nongowa Tra Cen Ii Group is requesting an 18,200,000 SLL loan through SMT to help members be in a better position to meet their immediate financial challenges. And at the end of each month, members can easily repay the loan using their monthly salaries. Martin will use his portion of the loan to buy house-building materials such as corrugated iron sheets, sand, cement, iron rods and other items to construct a house.

loans.use: to buy corrugated iron sheets, sand, cement, iron rods and other items to construct a house

loans.name: Stephanie

texts.en:
Stephanie is 40 years old. She is married with six children. She will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during rice production: they need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from her farming she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Liana

texts.en:
Liana is a distinguished educator and perfect specialist of Russian Language and Literature. She graduated from Yerevan State Linguistic University. For 25 years she worked at Vanadzor State Pedagogical Institute as a lecturer of Russian Language and Literature. Now, she is already a pensioner but she cannot give up, as she says, the mission of her life, that is, being a pedagogue. Now, she has a lot of pupils and students to whom she gives private courses preparing them for the entrance examinations, and also helps to write diploma works and candidate thesis. 
Liana lives in Vanadzor city in Lori region with her daughter who is already a very prosperous journalist. 
Liana says that nowadays it is very important to be able to teach by the help of modern technologies, and this is why she asks for this loan in order to buy a computer and a printer, which will be of great use in her work especially with students.

loans.use: to buy a computer and a printer, which will be of great use in her work especially with students.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers for farming.

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en:
Claudine is 29 years old. She will use this Kiva loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during rice production; they need to buy fertilizers in order to increase their production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that, in the future, she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter used the previous loan to buy a motorcycle. He has personal goals of educating his children and building a permanent house for a residence. He still complains of high fuel costs and mechanical breakdowns which cause him to spend a lot on motorcycle repairs. In spite of this, Peter is determined to buy more motorcycles for transport which will enable him to reap more profits. He is asking for a loan to buy another motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 50 years old. He will use this Kiva loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during rice production; they need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that, in the future, he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Marine

texts.en:
Marine lives with her family in the village Ddmashen in Geharkunik region. Marin graduated trading college in Yerevan city, but she never worked and the only occupation that she is engaged in is farming agriculture. With her husband, she perfectly takes care of her farm animals such as three cows, two calves, two horses, four piglets, 26 sheep and 20 chickens. She also has plot of land on which she cultivates a great range of vegetables, mainly for her family's use and some partly for sale. Marine is specialized in potato cultivation, which is the most typical vegetable for this region, and even among our people there is a kind of opinion that the best and the tastiest potato is raised in the Gegharkunik region; it seems to be the motherland of potato for Armenian people. 
That is why Marine decided to ask a loan from Kiva in order to buy potato seedlings of high quality and the organize cultivation of them, of course with hope that this deal with Kiva will be profitable for her family and also won’t be the last one.

loans.use: to buy potato seedlings of high quality and organize the cultivation of them.

loans.name: Tulibamu Farmers Kayanja Group

texts.en:
Charles is a 32-year-old married man with eight children, three of whom attend school. He lives in Kagadi, Uganda, where he works in construction. Charles has also been a farmer for the past ten years and is a hardworking, good, and honest man. His goal is to become self-employed and able to generate a good income. 

Charles is requesting a loan to buy maize and beans to sell. He is a member of Tulibamu Farmers Group Kayanja, a loan group where each member guarantees the others to get a loan since they don’t pledge securities. Charles hopes to grow his business despite the problems of inadequate capital and poor roads.

loans.use: to buy maize and beans to sell

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. She works raising livestock and she also sells coconuts.

Fatuma is requesting a loan to buy more coconuts for her business. She is grateful for the financial support she has received.

loans.use: to buy coconuts for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase another large refrigerator to make more cold water and ice to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice, oil cubes, onions, pepper, salt etc.

loans.name: Muzaffar

texts.ru:
Музаффару 58 лет  он хороший семьянин, имеет 4 детей. Музаффар занимается откормом скота, он каждое утро отправляет скот на пастбище чтобы те насытились и возвращаются вечером. Живут они в сельской местности. Чтобы иметь доход в семье, все члены семьи пытаются как-то зарабатывать деньги. Каждый трудится как может. Сам Музаффар занимается животноводством и выращиванием сельхозкультуры. От этого дела он получает хороший доход. Он выращивает в своём небольшом саду виноград. Хотя это сезонный бизнес, но он также приносит ему доход.

Основным и стабильным бизнесом Музаффара является животноводство. Он разводит и продаёт скот. В этом деле ему помогает жена и его дети. Они ухаживают за скотом, а также продают полученное от скота молоко. Бизнес животноводства приносит Музаффару хороший и стабильный доход. Поэтому он желает расширить этот бизнес. Ему необходимо купить ещё несколько голов скота для выращивания и дальнейшей продажи. Для этого Музаффару обратился в Арванд и хочет получить кредит на покупку скота. Он надеется, что этот бизнес будет успешно расширяться и приносить больше прибыли, чтобы качественно удовлетворять нужды семьи. Музаффар заранее благодарит Арванд за поддержку.
texts.en:
Muzaffar is 58 years old, and is a good family man with four children. Muzaffar raises cattle, and every morning he sends his cattle to pasture so they eat and return in the evening. They live in the countryside. To support the family, all family members try to earn money somehow. Everyone contributes, however they are able. Muzaffar works with livestock and crop production. He earns a good income from this business.  He also grows grapes in his small garden. Although this is a seasonal business, it brings him additional income.

Breeding and selling livestock is Muzaffar's core, stable business. His wife and children help him with the business by taking care of the cattle and selling the milk.  Because livestock provides such a good and stable income, Muzaffar wants to expand his business. He needs to buy a few additional cattle for breeding and resale. To achieve this, Muzaffar asked MDO Arvand for a loan to purchase cattle. He hopes that this expansion will successfully bring more profit to and improve quality of life for his family. Muzaffar thanks MDO Arvand in advance for their support.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Elisee

texts.en:
Elisee is 44 years old. He will use this Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during rice production; they need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that, in the future, he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during rice production.

Grace is aged 27. She is married with two children. She will use her Kiva loan to cover labour costs and fertilizer during rice production: she needs to buy fertilizers in order to increase her rice production. With the profits from her farming she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

loans.name: Kwekwe

texts.en:
Kwekwe is a hardworking and enterprising woman who lives in the coastal region of Kenya. Besides the local brew-preparing business, Kwekwe sells makuti (thatching materials made from palm leaves).

She is requesting for a loan to purchase more makuti for resale. She expects to do this without any difficulties, and to continue working without any problems.

loans.use: to purchase more makuti for resale.

loans.name: Domitira

texts.en:
Domitira is 47 years old. She will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and purchase fertilizer during rice production; She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from her farming, Domitira wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is appreciative of her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.
She is requesting a loan to purchase spare parts for her motorcycle. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for her motorcycle.

loans.name: Mealii

texts.en:
Mealii is a single with no children. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household consumables.

For over two years, she has operated a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women and curtains. She cites seasonality as her major challenge. 

With the loan, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business.

loans.name: Luvuno

texts.en:
Luvuno is a married woman with six children, one adult, four in school and one infant. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over two years, she has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation.  She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the loan, she wants to purchase stocks of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi appreciates Kiva lenders for her previous loan that improved her poultry business and enabled her get the profits that she used to improve her living standards.

Chizi is requesting a loan to pay for her children's school fees.  She joined Yehu to access financial support.

loans.use: to pay her children's school fees.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a hardworking and enterprising woman. She is married with five children. Four of her children are in school and one is underage. Fatuma works preparing dumplings to sell to neighbors and passersby. Her greatest business challenge is seasonality. Fatuma owns a house without electricity or running water and her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

Fatuma is requesting a loan to purchase wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil for her business

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma appreciates Kiva lenders for her previous loan that improved her fish-selling business and enabled her to get profits she used to improve her living standards.

Fatuma also operates a business selling meat goats. She is requesting a loan to purchase more goats for her business.

She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more goats for her business.

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en: Hanan is a conservative lady, so she asked her husband to take her place in the picture. Hanan was born in 1978. She is married and has two sons and one daughter. Her husband owns a mini market which is their only source of income. Hanan wants to help her husband with stocking his mini market with more food and home products so that he can raise his profit, as he doesn't have enough money to do so. For that, she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: to help her husband stock his mini market with food and home products

loans.name: Binata

texts.en:
Binata is a 28-year-old woman of Maynaguri. She lives with her husband, Suresh, and one son in the village Bagjan. She is illiterate and can sign her name only. She could not receive a basic education due to her parental monetary problems, but she is dedicated to providing a good education to her son. Her son is now too small to go to school.

Her husband is a farmer who cultivates different types of vegetables and sells them in the local market. Being a housewife, she manages all household work and then assists her husband in the farming activities. Both of them give hard labor to take care of their family but are unable to provide sufficient income.

Binata wants to extend her helping hands to her husband. She has decided to cultivate jute in her farm land as it is a most important and profitable crop and so she thinks this will be a lucrative business because jute fibers are commonly used in making ropes, bags, sacs, canvas, gunny bags, twine, carpets, curtains, twining threads and covers for cotton bales. 

She has taken the loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to purchase jute seeds and fertilizers to start cultivation as early as possible. She is very hopeful to earn profit from this new cultivation, which will help her to reach to her goals of giving a decent lifestyle to her family, educating her son become established in life and purchasing more farm lands for more cultivation.

Binata and her husband are very much thankful to the lenders (BJS and Kiva) for giving them the loan.

loans.use: To purchase jute seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for cultivating jute in her own farm land.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add an additional room, buy two refrigerators, and purchase milk, vegetarian products, candies and cleaning supplies

loans.name: Chandana

texts.en:
Chandana, 42 years old, is a married woman and mother of three children. She is from the rural village Anandanagar of Maynaguri in the district Jalpaiguri. All of her children are daily laborers who could not receive education due to their poverty. She has completed education up to grade 4 and her husband up to grade 8.
 
Chandana's husband is the only earner in the family. He runs a small business. It was very tough for Chandana to manage her household needs with the small income of her husband. Therefore, she decided to help her husband with her earning. For this purpose, she started her business of selling saris in her neighborhood. Sari is a garment consisting of a length of cotton or silk elaborately draped around the body, traditionally worn by women of India. 

She started her business from her house. She took the loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to buy different varieties of saris from the wholesale market to fulfill the demand of her customers. Her neighbors, relatives and friends are her main customers. Now she is playing an important role by giving financial support to her family. With the growing needs of her family, she stared her business to give financial support to her family. 

Chandana is a successful entrepreneur. She expects a boost in her earnings with her loan and her plans are to use the profit of her business for the betterment of her family members and also go ahead with her business.

She is grateful to BJS and Kiva for this loan.

loans.use: To buy a wide variety of saris for expanding her sari business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase shelving, a large refrigerator, a soft drink machine and stock.

loans.name: Bela

texts.en:
Bela is a 43-year-old woman. She lives with her husband, Subhash, and their only daughter in a small village Haspatalpara in Maynaguri in the district Jalpaiguri. She studied up to sixth grade and could not study further for the financial crisis of her family. Her husband is associated with business. Their daughter is in the madhyamik level of education.

Bela's husband has no permanent income, so it is very difficult to run the family smoothly. Bela has decided to start a dairy business. She is a hardworking lady and has the courage to go ahead in life. She keeps faith in her own ability. 

In order to start her business, she wants to purchase a dairy cow and for that she needs money. So she applied for a loan from BJS (Kiva’spartner). She will use the loan for purchasing a dairy cow to start her milk supply business. It will provide her a steady income to tide them over rough patches and allow them to save up for their daughter's future education. She wants to save money to construct a house for them to live in. 

She is thankful to her lenders BJS and Kiva for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for her milk supply business.

loans.name: Bela N Nabra - Domonaayili Group

texts.en:
Ayishetu is an active woman, 40 years old, from Demonayili in the Northern part of Ghana. She is married and has six children. She is the third person squatting and has both hands placed on the milled rice in their group picture. 
Ayishetu is a member of a local rice processing group who have been doing the business over the last 19 years. Their group is called ‘Bela N Nabra - Domonaayili’ Women Association. She makes good profits from the business since she and every member of her group have been trained by Grameen Ghana on improving ways of processing and milling locally-produced paddy rice for the local market in Ghana. Their milled rice is sold and consumed around Ghana and they are always in business.
Ayishetu and the group have asked for a loan of GHȼ 6,000. Her share of the loan will help her to buy and mill five bags of paddy rice. By so doing, she would earn more income and hence repay this loan and support her children’s educational and health needs.

loans.use: to buy and mill five bags of paddy rice.

loans.name: Shakilah Peninah

texts.en: Shakila Peninah used the previous loan to buy stock of second-hand clothes to sell and, with the proceeds, she has managed to change her lifestyle and that of her dependents. Shakilah Peninah still faces hardships of seasonal customers of the product she deals in plus price fluctuations. She maintains her vision of building rentals and transforming her business into a renowned boutique of second-hand clothes around town that can enable her to make more profits. Shakilah Peninah has asked for a loan to buy more stock of second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy more stock of second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is a 29-year-old married lady who is blessed with six children aged between 15 and 4 years. She has been in the farming business for a period of six years and is able to make an income of about 15,000 Kenya shillings every month, which is enough to cater to the family needs.

She has applied for her second loan with VisionFund Kenya and she plans to use it to buy a water tank which will help her in ensuring she has enough water to continue with her farming activities.

In the future, she would like to grow her business and purchase some solar panels for her home.

loans.use: to buy a water tank to support her farming activities.

loans.name: Donathile

texts.en:
Donathile is 50 years old. She will use her Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizer during rice production. They need to buy fertilizers in order to increase their production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and to support labor costs during rice production

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Elle  est âgée de  37 ans, célibataire sans enfant, et vit avec sa famille dans la ville de Koutiala. Elle n’a pas eu la chance de faire des études, raison pour laquelle elle s’est basée sur le commerce depuis à bas âge.  Elle exerce cette activité il y a  plus de 5 ans. Au Mali, le soumblala est l’un des condiments le plus important et très prisé par les femmes,  pour  cela cette  activité lui procure beaucoup de bénéfice car elle peut vendre plus de 2 gros paniers dans la semaine.  Pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’élargir son activité, Mlle a sollicité la collaboration avec  l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de 5 ans.   Elle a pris 3 prêts dans le groupe (prêt solidaire) tous  remboursés  correctement  et elle est à son 4ème  prêt en individuel dont les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter plus de 10 paniers  de Soumbala   auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente à Kayes et Bamako à une clientèle  de femmes  au comptant.  En plus de son fonds propre, elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 60.000FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le  remboursement de son prêt, subvenir à ses besoins et investir le reste dans son activité. 
Dans ses perspectives, Mlle compte élargir son activité.
texts.en:
She is 37 years old, single with no children and lives with her family in the city of Koutiala. She has not had the chance to study, which is why she focused on trade commerce from an early age. She has been carrying on this activity for over five years.

In Mali, soumbala (seed of the néré tree) is one of the most important condiments, and highly prized by women. This activity gives her good profits as she can sell more than two large baskets a week.

To increase her working capital and expand her business, she has been collaborating with the  Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution over the past five years. She participated in three group loans, all reimbursed correctly, and she is now on her fourth individual loan, having fully repaid the preceding ones.

With this loan she will buy more than ten baskets of soumbala from wholesalers. Sales are conducted in Kayes and Bamako, for cash to women customers.

In addition to her own funds, she relies on a monthly profit of 60,000 CFA francs she will use to repay the loan, meet her needs and reinvest the remainder in her activity.

Her future prospects are to expand her business.

loans.use: buy soumbala (seeds of the néré tree)

loans.name: Jean Marry Vianney

texts.en:
Jean Marry Vianney is 32 years old. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. 

Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and for labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
This is Mejumaa. Her previous loan was a big help in her business.  She has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing.
 
She would like to apply for a loan to purchase more bales of clothes for her business. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to purchase more bales of clothes for her business.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher is a 48-year-old married man with six children, living in Fort Portal, Uganda. 

He deals in selling matooke (green plantains) and selling milk. He faces inadequate labor, but he hopes to have a good retirement. 

Christopher needs a loan to buy two good hybrid bulls for his farm.

loans.use: to buy two good hybrid bulls for his farm.

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is a married woman who has six children, five in school and one underage. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Mwaka has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and villagers. Her greatest monthly challenge is the high cost of transportation.

She is requesting a loan to purchase charcoal for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Mesaidi

texts.en:
Mesaidi is a hardworking and enterprising woman who owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. She is a married woman with four children, two in school and two underage.

Mesaidi sells goat meat to her neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge. With the loan, she wants to purchase more goats for her business. She joined Yehu to boast her business.

loans.use: to purchase more goats for her business

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
This is Fatuma. She previously accessed a loan that she used in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenditures.

Fatuma is requesting a loan to purchase more goats for resale. She appreciates Kiva for their financial support.

Fatuma looks forward to this financial increase with happiness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to purchase more goats for resale

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

She would like to apply for a loan to buy more stock of maize and rice to sell. 

She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of maize and rice for to sell.

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
This is Mwaka. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. 

She would like to apply for a loan to buy more stock of goats and sheep for her business. 

Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. 

She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart

loans.use: to buy more stock of goats and sheep for her business.

loans.name: Reyhan

texts.en:
Reyhan is married and is the mother of two grown children. She also has grandchildren. 

For 25 years, Reyhan has made dumplings, phyllo sheets, tomato paste, tomato sauce and jams at home. At first she began selling them to her circle of friends, but as people got to know her products, her customer base increased, and she now even receives orders from Istanbul. With the loan from Maya, Reyhan intends to buy a mixer for kneading dough. “I did it by hand [for a long time] and my arms now hurt. A mixer will make things easier for me,” she said. It will also help her to work faster. Her dream is to one day open a shop and sell her products there.

Translated from Turkish by Maya Staff 
Reyhan Hanım evli ,yetişkin iki çocuğu ve torunları var.  Reyhan Hanım  yirmi beş senedir evde mantı,el yufkası,salça,domates suyu,reçel yapıp satıyor.  İlk önceleri çevresine satıyor ,yaptığı ürünler beğenilince müşterileri artıyor.  İstanbul ‘dan siparişler alıyor.  Aldığı kredi ile bir tane hamur yoğurma makinası alacak.  ”Artık ellerim ve kollarım ağrıyor,bu makine bana kolaylık sağlayacak”dedi.  İşlerini daha çabuk yapacağını belirtti.  Tek hayali bir dükkan açmak ve yaptığı el ürünlerini  burada satmak olduğunu belirtti.

loans.use: to buy a mixer for kneading dough

loans.name: Mariana De Jesus

texts.es:
La tortilla es un alimento básico que nunca falta en la mayoría de los hogares del país. María de Jesús es experta en su elaboración.  Su casa huele a maíz y leña, lo que atrae a todos los vecinos de su comunidad,  que  se rinden ante la tentación de los olores que llegan hasta sus viviendas.  Su esfuerzo ha rendido frutos, ya que las ventas  van aumentando cada día. 
Su máxima inspiración son sus hijos. Ella desea brindarles un futuro próspero. María de Jesús anhela que su negocio crezca y se convierta en la mejor tortillería de su comunidad, por lo que solicitó un préstamo en KIVA MiCrédito, para la compra de Maiz y Leña ya que esta institución apoya a pequeños comerciantes como ella. Las ganancias serán destinadas para mejorar la infraestructura de su hogar.
texts.en:
María de Jesús is an expert maker of tortillas, a staple food that nearly all Nicaraguan families always have in their homes. The tortilla business that she runs in her home attracts neighbors and people from across her community, who are drawn by the scent of corn and firewood. María's efforts have borne fruit as her sales are growing steadily by the day. 

María's greatest motivation is her children and the desire to ensure that they have a prosperous future. María hopes that her business will grow into the best tortilla business in the community. She's therefore applied for a microloan from Kiva, which supports small business owners like her, for the purchase of corn and firewood. María plans to use the income from her business to make improvements to her family's home.

loans.use: to purchase corn and firewood.

loans.name: Elina

texts.en:
Elina is married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past four years she has operated a retail shop  business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality  as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the loan, she wants to purchase soap, wheat flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil. 

Elina decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase soap, wheat flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking  oil

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en:
Nadia was born in 1978. She is married and has one son. 

Nadia is seeking to provide her son with a better life, so she started her business selling rabbits and chicken products two years ago. As her business was profitable, she decided to expand by purchasing more rabbits and chickens, and bringing more food for them as well. But she doesn't have enough money to do so. For that, she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more rabbits and chicken along with food for them.

loans.name: Rahim

texts.ru:
Рахиму 64 года, он женат имеет 3 детей. Он имеет среднее образование, работает в частной компании по изготовлению вентиляционных труб и сварочных работ. Жена Рахима  работает в кондитерском цеху , она печет различные печеные. Дети Рахима живут и работают в РФ, и каждый раз помогают высылая денежные переводы на его имя. 
Его одна из дочерей уже совсем выросла и Рахим планирует выдать её замуж. Все что он зарабатывает уходит на проживание и они вместе с женой никак не могут накопить денег. Рахиму хочет отремонтировать свой дом так как дом нуждается в обновлении, и в плохих условиях он не может пригласить домой гостей. Но на ремонт он не имеет достаточно денежных средств. Посоветовавшись с родными он решил получить кредит в Арванде. На полученный кредит Рахиму планирует провести ремонт и обновить мебель. Надеется, что в Арванде его финансово поддержат и помогут в осуществлении его планов. Он думает, что его  дом приобретет новый облик, когда он установит новую купленную мебель.  Его главная цель с кредита заключается в дальнейшем заботиться о своей семье, покрывая свои ежедневные потребности. Его  мечта,  чтобы его семья жила в хороших условиях.
texts.en:
Rahim is 64 years old, is married and has three children. He has a high school education, works for a private company that makes ventilation pipes and provides welding services. Rahim's wife works in the confectionery shop, where she bakes a variety of cookies. Rahim's children live and work in Russia, and consistently help by sending money back.

One of his daughters has grown up and Rahim plans to marry her. He and his wife spend all of their earnings supporting themselves, and are unable to save money. Rahim wants to renovate his house since it is in need of updating and is in too poor a condition to invite any guests to the house. However, he doesn't have sufficient funds to pay for the repairs. 

After consulting with his family, he decided to get a loan from MDO Arvand. With this loan, Rahim plans to fix his house and buy new furniture. He hopes that MDO Arvand will financially support him and help in carrying out his plans. He thinks his house will get a new look, especially when he sets up the newly purchased furniture. His main objective is to take care of his family, and cover their daily needs. His dream is for his family to live in good conditions.

loans.use: to buy furniture

loans.name: Binyomo 3 Group

texts.en:
These ladies are part of the Binyomo 3 group and in their ninth loan cycle. They are all participating in fish and waakye (cooked rice and beans) businesses.

The group representative is Naomi, who sells fish. She is well-experienced in this business and has trained many young ladies in this trade. She is 41 years old and married with three dependable children. Naomi has been able to improve her life, family and her income with her previous loans and this one would go a long way to improve her business very much. She is requesting this loan to purchase four cartons of fish to sell to customers. This will help her firm up her business plan, which will help her improve her profits.

Harriet is a waakye seller and Ogbede is a fish seller. They are requesting a total loan amount of 5,600 GHS to improve their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase four cartons of fish

loans.name: Chandana

texts.en:
Chandana is a 21-year-old woman of Maynaguri. Her husband, Sanjay, is a small-business man. She lives with her husband and one son. She has completed secondary level education. Her son is too small to go to school.
 
Their income is not sufficient for paying household expenses and raising her son as well, and that is why Chandana has to face lots of financial hurdles. For this reason she decided to help her husband and contribute to her family. 

She has her own sewing business.She applied for a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to invest in her sewing business for making more cotton garments, blouses, petticoats, frocks, etc. As she has a sound knowledge of stitching from her childhood, she has chosen this sewing business to start. She hopes she can earn well from this business because there is no good tailor nearby, and people have to go to the proper town to fulfill their needs. Due to this demand of daily use garments in her locality, Chandana decided to invest in her sewing business with a hope that she will earn huge profit. 

With the profit, she hopes to raise her child smoothly, not to affect him from poverty and to compensate for family’s financial hurdles.

Now Chandana is becoming a renowned tailor in her locality and gives her thanks to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for her own sewing business.

loans.name: Rub

texts.en:
Rub is a 42-year-old married woman of Maynaguri. She has completed her secondary level education. She is blessed with two children who are now students of grade 6 and 7. Her husband is associated with a small business. He sells clothing door to door. Rub also helps her husband in this business. But due to lack of money, her husband could not purchase a large variety and good quality of clothes. Thus they are unable to fulfill the needs of their customers. 

Rub decided to help her husband by taking a loan from (Kiva’s partner) BJS of INR 15,000 to purchase a lot of different types of clothes as per the demand. They have a future plan to open a shop of their own so they can do business on a larger scale and reach to more customers. She hopes she can upgrade her family and increase their financial status with the profit from the business.

Rub thanks BJS and Kiva a lot for their funding support.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for retail sales.

loans.name: Fidane

texts.en:
Fidane, who has been a long-time client of VisionFund Albania, is requesting a loan of 50,000 Albanian Lek (ALL) to pay for her medical expenses. Lately, she has been having very strong headaches and dizziness that don’t seem to stop and the family doctor has suggested that she see a specialist immediately. At first she neglected the visitation, thinking that it was just something that would go away, but now she’s convinced that there is something serious according to her.  
The activity of her focus has been agriculture; particularly, she’s been planting and selling beans and wheat. Fidane lives in a little village in southeastern Albania about 899 meters above sea level. Villagers here are hard-workers and they pursue mostly agriculture/livestock and horticulture. Bacon and pickles are the foods that are prepared during the summertime for the winter.

loans.use: to pay for a medical visitation.

loans.name: Sarobala

texts.en:
Sarobala is a 31-year-old hardworking married woman. She has two children to rise. Sarobala lives in a small town Maynaguri of Jalpaiguri district with her husband, Paresh.

Her husband is a farmer by profession. They have their own land, where they cultivate varieties of crops. His husband sells the crops to the wholesale market after the harvest. Now Sarobala and her husband plan to cultivate jute and decided to take a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS to buy seeds and fertilizers. She has decided to grow jute as jute is a very popular and profitable crop in their area. She hopes she can generate more income through this harvest. 

She hopes to construct a concrete house with the profit from her jute business. Now Sarobala is running her agribusiness successfully. She is thankful to BJS and Kiva for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers for jute cultivation.

loans.name: La Nouvelle Alliance Group

texts.fr: La cliente Bahati est une vaillante commerçante, présidente et membre du groupe d’affaires «La Nouvelle Alliance», senior entrepreneur, dynamique, âgée de 43 ans, mariée et mère de 11 enfants, qui tous étudient.  Elle est vendeuse des divers produits d’alimentation. Elle installe sa marchandise dans une alimentation à son domicile dans un Quartier animé, où, elle a su gagner sa clientèle. Elle commença ses affaires avec le premier capital reçu de son mari. Son conjoint est un hôtelier. Plus tard, elle bénéficia le prêt de l’IMF Hekima. Elle y a 15 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. Ce nouveau prêt va la servir d’acheter 3 sacs de farine de format, 2 cartons du lait en poudre, 2 sacs de sucre, 2 carton de vin, 3 cartons de jus, 5 cartons d’eau vive, 60 litres d’huile, biscuits, bombons etc. Ainsi, elle souhaite accroitre son capital, scolariser, nourrir ses enfants.  Au finish, elle remercie  fortement Hekima pour l’autonomisation des  petits entrepreneurs exclus du système bancaire classique, surtout;  pendant ce moment difficile post conflits dans la région de l’Est du pays.
texts.en:
Bahati, age 43, is a dynamic and hard-working merchant, and a member of the business group “La Nouvelle Alliance” of which she is also the president. A senior entrepreneur, she is married with 11 children who all attend school. 

Bahati sells various food products. She sets up her merchandise in a grocery store located in a busy area of the sector where she lives, and where she has built a customer base. She initially started her business with capital given by her husband, a hotel operator. She later turned to the Hekima MFI for financial assistance. She has been practicing this activity for 15 years. 

This new loan will help her to buy 3 sacks of flour, 2 cartons of powdered milk, 2 sacks of sugar, 2 cartons of wine, 3 cartons of juice, 5 cartons of spring water, 60 litres of oil, some cookies, candy, etc. 

Her goals are to bolster her capital, feed her children and provide for their education. 

Bahati wishes to thank Hekima for helping to empower small business owners who cannot use the traditional banking system, especially in these post-war times in the Eastern region.

loans.use: to buy 3 sacks of flour, 2 cartons of powdered milk, 2 sacks of sugar, 2 cartons of wine, 3 cartons of juice, 5 cartons of spring water, 60 liters of oil, some cookies, candy, etc.

loans.name: Mnyazi

texts.en:
Mnyazi is married and has six children, three of whom are in school while three are adults. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Mnyazi has operated a fruits selling business for the past two years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts, bananas, oranges and mangoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of coconuts, bananas, oranges and mangoes for resale.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is married with two school-going children. They live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanaisha has operated fruit and vegetable stall for the past one year. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini green grocer's in the future.

With the loan, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Selina

texts.en: Selina appreciates her previous Kiva loan, that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.  She is requesting a loan to purchase bales of clothes for resale . She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mwanadawa

texts.en:
Mwanadawa is a married woman with five children, two of whom are in school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and price fluctuation as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the loan, she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married and has nine school-going children. They live at their own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Fatuma has operated a fruit and vegetable stall for the past five years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini green grocer's in the future.

With the loan, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more charcoal and groundnuts for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more cooking oil, rice and seasonings to expand her cookery business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more dry fish, rice, oil and cubes etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase caustic soda for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy an electric grinder and a big pot

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice, a repeat borrower, has applied for a loan of 2,000,000 UGX to buy materials for making clothes for sale in her business. She is a very hard-working lady,  dedicating 9 hours a day and six days a week to her business. There is a demand for her clothes since her prices are affordable which makes her have many sales therefore making a profit. Her desire is to get more capital to grow her business to a good standard. 

Beatrice's future plans are to educate all her children. She however hopes that the problem of limited capital will soon be history especially if  she continues to get a financial boost from Ugafode.

loans.use: To buy materials for sewing

loans.name: Minata

texts.fr:
Mme est âgée de 42 ans, elle vit dans une grande famille dans la ville  de Koutiala. Elle n’a pas eu la chance de continuer les études, d’où son attachement aux activités commerciales. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités, présentement elle s’est basée sur  la vente d’aliments.  Pour  pouvoir constituer un stocke de matières premières (farine de blé, huile, pomme de terre, viandes etc. …) et  augmenter son chiffre d’affaire, elle décide de  rejoindre l‘institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso, dont elle est à son premier prêt.
Avec ce prêt  elle compte acheter quelques sacs de farine, Litres d’huile, 2 sacs de pommes de terre et faire de sandwich.  Elle  effectue sa vente à Koutiala à une clientèle mixte.
Elle compte  réaliser un profit de 60.000FCFA par mois, qu’elle utilisera  pour  le remboursement des intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso, subvenir à ses besoins et investir le reste dans  son activité. 
Elle compte toujours sur les financements  de Soro Yiriwaso pour l’agrandissement et la diversification de son activité.
texts.en:
This lady is 42 years old. She lives in a large family in the city of Koutiala. She has not had the opportunity to pursue her schooling, hence her attachment to commercial activities. 

After conducting several activities, she is currently focused on selling food preparations. To set up a supply of raw materials (wheat flour, oil, potatoes, meats, etc.) and increase her turnover, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, where she is on her first loan.

With this loan she will buy a few bags of flour, litres of cooking oil, two bags of potatoes and will make sandwiches. She conducts her sales in Koutiala to a mixed clientele.

She expects to make monthly profits of 60,000 CFA francs she will use to repay the Soro Yiriwaso interests, meet her needs and reinvest the remainder in her activity.

She is still counting on funding from Soro Yiriwaso to expand and diversify her business.

loans.use: buy ingredients for food preparations

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en:
Sylivia lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with two children, one of whom attends school. She is also looking after her grandfather. She has been selling green bananas, tomatoes, and onions at retail in the market for the last ten years, working seven days a week. She also does some farming and sells the farm produce in order to earn more income.

She has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Uganda Shillings from MCDT SACCO to enable her to stock more green bananas, tomatoes, oranges, and onions. Her challenges include thieves. Her dream is to upgrade from retail to wholesale, supplying other kinds of farm produce from her own farm. She joined MCDT to ensure timely loans.

She and her husband live in a rented house with access to electricity but no piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent.

loans.use: To buy green bananas, tomatoes, oranges, and onions.

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with one school-going child. She is not looking after any other members of the family. She has been selling shoes wholesale from the market for five years, working six days a week. She does not have any other source of income.

Aidah has requested a loan of Ugandan Shillings 1,200,000 from MCDT-SACCO to be able to stock more shoes for sale.  Her challenges include seasonality. Her dream is to become an importer of both new and second-hand shoes. She joined MCDT- SACCO because of the relatively low interest charged on loans and to save for a house that she plans to build. 

She stays in a rented house with access to electricity but no piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy a bale of used shoes

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a farmer, age 42 years old. He is married with six children, ages 20, 19, 17, 15, 13, and 11 years old, and all attending school. He has applied for a loan of 5,000,000 shillings to buy mulches and fertilizers to use on his farm. He started his business in 1994 in a rural area in Nkinga B, Nkungu Mitooma, Ruhinda, to have an income to sustain himself and his rather large family. He is a hardworking man, who works 10 hours a day and 6 days a week. His clients are coffee traders. He also has a grinding machine for milling millet to earn more income. He is faced with the challenge of competition with other farmers, but he works hard to beat the competition since the demands of his family are many. He hopes to be financially stable when given the loan money so that he can adequately provide for his family. He appreciates the great work being done by Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy mulch

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cigarettes, drinks and biscuits to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more slippers for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more cooking oil, rice, and cooking seasonings to expand her business.

loans.name: Angel Julio

texts.es:
El señor Ángel es un veterano de mil batallas vividas a lo largo de su vida, vive en el municipio de Sincelejo con su esposa y un hijo que tiene en la universidad.
El es un hombre muy trabajador y desde hace algún tiempo viene trabajando en el negocio de la ebanistería. Su negocio consiste en la compra y venta de muebles a través de catalogo. El ofrece sus productos de manera ambulante y cuando un cliente le hace un pedido de un mueble, el lo manda a hacer de acuerdo a los gustos de dicho cliente.
Manifiesta que es un negocio muy lucrativo y sencillo de realizar para su edad.
El solicita un préstamo para compra de muebles al por mayor y compra de materia prima para su fabricación.
El préstamo le dará la oportunidad de capitalizar su negocio y de darle un impulso considerable a su actividad, permitiéndole obtener recursos para la universidad de su hijo.
texts.en:
Señor Ángel is a veteran of a thousand battles that he has lived throughout his life.  He lives in the municipality of Sincelejo with his wife, and a son whom he has in the university. 

He is a very hardworking man, and for some time he has been working in the furniture business. His business consists in purchasing and selling furniture through a catalog.  He sells his products on foot, and when a customer places an order for a piece of furniture, he orders it made according to that customer’s tastes.  He says that it is a business that is lucrative and easy for him to run at his age.

He is requesting a loan for the purchase of wholesale furniture, and of materials for making it.  The loan will give him the opportunity to fund his business, and it will give his activity a considerable boost, allowing him to make the money for his son’s university education.

loans.use: to purchase furniture to sell, and materials for making it.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy beans and condiments

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy used clothes for her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay school/college fees for his children

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy house building materials for the construction of a dwelling house for her family

loans.name: Julio César

texts.en:
Julio César is a Kubo Financiero client, and this is his story: 

Julio is 29 years old and lives with his parents in a house they have owned for his whole life. He has two sons, who live with their mother since Julio separated from her a couple of years ago. Along with his father, he owns a sheet shop and car painting and repairing workshop, which has been open for 8 years now. Julio asks for this loan to invest in his business and improve the work he can handle; specifically, he wants to buy a compressor. His motivation is to keep working hard in order to be able to provide a good standard of living for his children.

loans.use: to buy a compressor machine for his mechanic workshop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more flour, sugar and cooking oil

loans.name: S.l.m.b.corr Field Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, Northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you this group of teachers from one of the schools in Bo, Sierra Leone’s second capital city. Teachers of this school have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, for a loan of SLL 9,500,000 in order to improve their standards of living. Some of them will use this loan to buy house building materials, some to buy pieces of furniture, others to pay school fees for their children and so on. At the end of each month, they will repay the loan. It is their school’s bursar who is directly responsible to deduct their repayment amount, and they pay SMT.  

Augustine is the featured leader of this group of teachers.  40-year-old Augustine was born in Bo city. He is a teacher, and has been in the teaching profession for 16 years now. Augustine is married to a state registered nurse, and they have one child who is attending secondary school. 

Augustine requested this loan in order to buy house building materials, like iron corrugated sheets, sand, etc., for the construction of a dwelling house for his family.

loans.use: to buy house building materials for the construction of a dwelling house for his family

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay school fess for his children

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more blood syrup, malarial drugs and pain tablets to expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy disposable serving items and kitchen utensils

loans.name: Blema Tesaa Group

texts.en:
These women live in Teshie, a neighborhood of Accra, and they know each other as neighbors. The group members work as vendors, selling groceries, assorted soaps, cloth and underwear. With the goal of bolstering their working capital, the group members have decided to collaborate with ID-Ghana and are now on their forth loan cycle.

Rebecca is well-known in the entire neighborhood as a vendor of high-quality groceries. She plans to use her loan to buy groceries and assorted soaps, from the wholesale market in Accra. The groceries will be sold to customers. She promises to be ever ready, to retail to a customer base composed mainly of local women. With this loan, Rebecca hopes to earn good monthly revenue, which will be reinvested in her business. She is 57 years old and lives alone.

The group members need a total amount of GHS 3100 to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy groceries and assorted soaps to sell

loans.name: Rosedek Group

texts.en:
This group consists of five members. The featured borrower is Nancy. She is 36 years old and married with three children. She sells fish in her community. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy three cartons of fish, which she will sell to customers. With this loan, Nancy has been able to increase her merchandise and her earnings. 

The other members are as follows:
Edith is 36 years old and sells fish from her home.
Peter, age 35, sells insecticides and other chemicals in his community.
Mercy, age 38, sells pastries through hawking.
Mary, age 42, sells rice and tomatoes. 

This group is on its fifth loan cycle with ID-Ghana. They have demonstrated that they are responsible members and have the spirit to succeed.

loans.use: To buy three cartons of fish, which she will sell to customers.

loans.name: Jose Rutilio

texts.es:
El señor José se dedica a la venta de distintos tipos de mercancía tales como implementos para el hogar, accesorios, cuadros, entre otros hace más de 15 años, lo hace con el fin de obtener recursos para su propio sostenimiento ya que vive solo. Sus hijos ya son adultos y tiene una vida aparte.
El pide un préstamo para comprar un inventario de mercancía mucho más amplio y poder ofrecer a sus clientes una mayor variedad de productos.
Su principal dificultad es la delicada situación de salud en la que ahora se encuentra y que en muchas ocasiones se ha tenido que ver obligado a detener su negocio por temporadas.
Es un hombre sencillo y humilde, le gusta trabajar y salir adelante.
Tiene el sueño de poder tener casa propia y vivir en paz.
texts.en:
Joseph sells various types of merchandise such as household goods and decor, accessories, paintings, among other things.  He has been in this business for 15 years.  He does it to obtain income for his own support as he is living alone.  His children are grown and have a their own life.

He asks for a loan to buy a larger inventory of merchandise and offer his customers a wider range of products.

His main difficulty is the delicate situation in which health is now and that often he has had to stop his seasonal business.  He is a simple and humble man; he likes to work and succeed.  He has the dream of home ownership and to live in peace.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise wholesale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for his boys' school expenses.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel is a Kubo Financiero client, and this is her story:

Isabel is 50 years old, single, and has a 28-year-old son. She lives in a house with relatives, where her sisters, nephews, and grandsons live.

She makes a living selling jewelry pieces, mostly to friends and family. She also has some customers in downtown Mexico City, who have been sent to her via a recommendation. She explains that this is an especially good season for her business, because of school graduations.

She asks for this loan to buy merchandise and be prepared for this good season of sales that is coming up. Isabel’s motivation to keep working is to have a better house, which she says is her main goal.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for the upcoming graduation season

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his children's education.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine, chair, and fabric.

loans.name: Peka

texts.en:
Peka is a 33-year-old mother of five children. She enlarged her plantation, as a means of earning extra income for the family. They have been doing this for more than three years. Peka also sells cigarettes, because she believes she earns quite a good profit from it.

Peka plans to use this loan she is getting from SPBD, to purchase chemicals, fertilizer, and a mist blower for her plantation business, boxes of cigarettes to sell, and timber, cement, iron roofing, and a toilet bowl to renovate her bathroom. Peka joined SPBD to gain access to credit, to assist her in improving the living standard of her family by being an innovative entrepreneur.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for crop growing, cigarettes to sell, and materials with which to renovate her bathroom

loans.name: Menime

texts.en:
Menime is a 33-year-old, married mother of three children. She operates a canteen business and has been doing this for two years. According to her, it has earned her quite a lot of money. Her husband assists her, when she needs help for her canteen. She sells at the schools in her village and also to the public, who are from neighboring villages.

She plans to use this loan to purchase more ingredients for her canteen, such as bread, eggs, mayonnaise, onion for sandwiches, sacks of rice, a box of chicken leg quarters, cooking oil for her cooked-chicken-and-rice meal, plastic bags, milk, sugar, and foam cups for her tea or coffee. Menime has managed to improve her family's living standard, with the profits she has made from her business. She has met their everyday needs, also.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients for her canteen, such as bread, eggs, and mayonnaise

loans.name: Vavao

texts.en:
Vavao is a 57-year-old mother of eight children. She has a small plantation business, which has been in existence for more than five years. She sells her produce to the public or people within her village. Her husband and children help out when needed. 

With this money she is requesting, Vavao plans to purchase a mist blower, chemicals, spades, shovels, bushknives, and gloves for her plantation business. 

She joined SPBD in order to gain access to capital, and with the profits that she has been getting, she has managed to provide for her family's essential daily needs.

loans.use: to purchase a mist blower, chemicals, spades, shovels, bushknives, and gloves.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a new chair and renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a sewing machine, table and overlock sewing machine.

loans.name: Moila

texts.en:
Moila is a 68-year-old, married mother of 10 children. Though some of her kids have found employment to help out with her family, she still wants to be useful and use her talents to earn some extra money, without relying heavily on her kids. She bakes goods and delivers them to schools and nearby shops around her village, to be sold.

She has just joined the SPBD program, in order to gain access to financial assistance. She has witnessed the other members of SPBD being able to support themselves, through this assistance. Moila plans to use this loan to purchase the ingredients for her bakery business, such as sacks of flour, sacks of sugar, cooking oil, yeast, eggs, icing sugar, cake mix, baking powder, and butter.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients for her bakery business, such as sacks of flour, sacks of sugar, and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for his sister's education.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for his children's school expenses.

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Marcela es una mujer de 38 años de edad soltera y madre de 3 hijos.
Sus hijos a su corta edad son expertos en el arte de tejer y juntos toda la familia se dedica al tejido artesanal en mantas de lana.
Marcela es una pequeña microempresaria que sostiene a su familia realizando tejidos y otras actividades como el transporte para el servicio público mediante un vehículo que aún no termina de pagar.
Su familia fue creciendo y su situación económica se puso un poco difícil, es por eso que se le ocurrió la idea de adquirir un automóvil para el uso de transporte público con la esperanza de que algún día sus hijos lo puedan administrar, si bien sus negocios prosperan y rinden Marcela y sus hijos no terminan de pagar su automóvil, esto no los deja desenvolverse libremente en el arte de los tejidos y pierden clientela y ventas. El hijo mayor de marcela tiene 15 años y quiere aprende a manejar el automóvil para dejar de pagarla  al chofer que contrataron, los 2 hijos menores se ocupan de hilvanar la lana de oveja y alpaca que su mama compra de una comunidad vecina del altiplano, es por eso que marcela solicita el préstamo para terminar de pagar su vehículo y comprar lana de oveja y alpaca.
texts.en:
Marcela is 38 years old, and she is single, with three children.  Her children, at their young age, are experts in the art of weaving; and the whole family works together making hand-woven woolen blankets.

Marcela is a small businesswoman who supports her family by weaving and other activities, such as a public taxi service that she operates, using a vehicle that she has not yet finished paying for.
